issue.title: credentials for http proxy when using default_urllb3_manager()
issue.body:
I need to clone a `git+https://` repo behind an HTTP proxy. Unfortunately, Poetry will rely on the default urllib3.PoolManager generated by `default_urllib3_manager()` ([code](https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/blob/cd0990259901351400deda93b529ec601cfa52e8/dulwich/client.py#L1797)). And that default generator misses a critical part: **it won't populate the credentials in the `proxy_header` parameter**.

This is a critical part because HTTPS over HTTP proxy requires tunneling (see urllib3 implementation `connection_requires_http_tunnel()` [here](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/4e98d57809dacab1cbe625fddeec1a290c478ea9/src/urllib3/util/proxy.py#L11))

... and when using tunneling, the proxy credentials should be in `Proxy-Authorization: Basic XXXX` header. Otherwise it is nowhere else.

Suggestion: when proxy_url contains a username+password => populate the `proxy_header` with `Proxy-Authorization: Basic XXXX`

_Originally posted by @raphaeljoie in https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/issues/822#issuecomment-1779787418_

comment.body: We're passing proxy_url (including any credentials) to ProxyManager. If the authentication header needs to be constructed manually, happy to merge a PR that splits the URL and passes proxy_headers.

issue.title: Because Poetry relies on Dulwich, I kind of have the same issue.
issue.body:
Because Poetry relies on Dulwich, I kind of have the same issue.

I need to clone a `git+https://` repo behind an HTTP proxy. Unfortunately, Poetry will rely on the default urllib3.PoolManager generated by `default_urllib3_manager()` ([code](https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/blob/cd0990259901351400deda93b529ec601cfa52e8/dulwich/client.py#L1797)). And that default generator misses a critical part: **it won't populate the credentials in the `proxy_header` parameter**.

This is a critical part because HTTPS over HTTP proxy requires tunneling (see urllib3 implementation `connection_requires_http_tunnel()` [here](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/4e98d57809dacab1cbe625fddeec1a290c478ea9/src/urllib3/util/proxy.py#L11))

... and when using tunneling, the proxy credentials should be in `Proxy-Authorization: Basic XXXX` header. Otherwise it is nowhere else.

Suggestion: when proxy_url contains a username+password => populate the `proxy_header` with `Proxy-Authorization: Basic XXXX`

_Originally posted by @raphaeljoie in https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/issues/822#issuecomment-1779787418_

issue.title: Support callback-based authentication for HTTP and HTTP proxies
issue.body: I've managed to get HTTP authentication working in `hg-git` by intercepting `dulwich.client.HTTPUnauthorized`, but this has some issues. First of all, it doesn't distinguish between the HTTP call itself and the proxy, and it doesn't reveal the scheme — which is used by Mercurial's password manager.

comment.body: @raphaeljoie please file a separate issue, that's different from this one.

issue.title: Support callback-based authentication for HTTP and HTTP proxies
issue.body: I've managed to get HTTP authentication working in `hg-git` by intercepting `dulwich.client.HTTPUnauthorized`, but this has some issues. First of all, it doesn't distinguish between the HTTP call itself and the proxy, and it doesn't reveal the scheme — which is used by Mercurial's password manager.

comment.body:
Because Poetry relies on Dulwich, I kind of have the same issue.

I need to clone a `git+https://` repo behind an HTTP proxy. Unfortunately, Poetry will rely on the default urllib3.PoolManager generated by `default_urllib3_manager()` ([code](https://github.com/jelmer/dulwich/blob/cd0990259901351400deda93b529ec601cfa52e8/dulwich/client.py#L1797)). And that default generator misses a critical part: **it won't populate the credentials in the `proxy_header` parameter**.

This is a critical part because HTTPS over HTTP proxy requires tunneling (see urllib3 implementation `connection_requires_http_tunnel()` [here](https://github.com/urllib3/urllib3/blob/4e98d57809dacab1cbe625fddeec1a290c478ea9/src/urllib3/util/proxy.py#L11))

... and when using tunneling, the proxy credentials should be in `Proxy-Authorization: Basic XXXX` header. Otherwise it is nowhere else.

Suggestion: when proxy_url contains a username+password => populate the `proxy_header` with `Proxy-Authorization: Basic XXXX`

issue.title: Dulwich Git history contains invalid objects
issue.body:
The Dulwich Git history contains a few ".git" directories in early commits, at a time when C git still allowed this.

from "git fsck --full":

warning in tree eaea53f8085ad0f9cd299b534774dfaef2bc26f1: hasDotgit: contains '.git'
warning in tree e5f1393aeea756d43d574504d932a887a36f1ce8: hasDotgit: contains '.git'
warning in tree de750728425824837d8e774361b1033cbc0f2843: hasDotgit: contains '.git'
warning in tree 4d73ba3255064784acec2a5102790c707d042043: hasDotgit: contains '.git'
warning in tree eaea53f8085ad0f9cd299b534774dfaef2bc26f1: hasDotgit: contains '.git'

github now refuses packs with trees like this.

Unfortunately the only way to fix this is to rewrite history :(

comment.body:
If you wanted to work on it, I think here is a possible way to approach this:

1) Provide a script to rewrite history, and add a headsup in README about what we're doing
2) We can provide a revised branch in this repository for a while
3) Make sure we're happy with the rewritten history
4) Switch over

If we're going to do this, there is at least one other thing we should fix. IIRC there is a commit with a dropped digit for the timestamp somewhere in history, which means that it is reported as being decades old rather than from 2014 or so - we should probably fix that at the same time.

issue.title: Dulwich passes through IncompleteRead from urllib3
issue.body:
We hit this in CI, most likely due to network issues
```
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 816, in fetch
            result = self.fetch_pack(
                     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 2146, in fetch_pack
            _handle_upload_pack_tail(
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 606, in _handle_upload_pack_tail
            for chan, data in _read_side_band64k_data(proto.read_pkt_seq()):
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 497, in _read_side_band64k_data
            for pkt in pkt_seq:
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/protocol.py", line 275, in read_pkt_seq
            pkt = self.read_pkt_line()
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/protocol.py", line 223, in read_pkt_line
            pkt_contents = read(size - 4)
                           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 879, in read
            data = self._raw_read(amt)
                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 813, in _raw_read
            with self._error_catcher():
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/contextlib.py", line 155, in __exit__
            self.gen.throw(typ, value, traceback)
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 727, in _error_catcher
            raise ProtocolError(f"Connection broken: {e!r}", e) from e
        urllib3.exceptions.ProtocolError: ('Connection broken: IncompleteRead(7577 bytes read)', IncompleteRead(7577 bytes read))
```
We would expect this to result in GitProtocolError.

comment.body: Happy to merge PRs that wrap urllib3.exceptions.ProtocolError in a GitProtocolError.

issue.title: Dulwich passes through IncompleteRead from urllib3
issue.body:
We hit this in CI, most likely due to network issues
```
            remote_refs = client.fetch(
                          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 816, in fetch
            result = self.fetch_pack(
                     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 2146, in fetch_pack
            _handle_upload_pack_tail(
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 606, in _handle_upload_pack_tail
            for chan, data in _read_side_band64k_data(proto.read_pkt_seq()):
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/client.py", line 497, in _read_side_band64k_data
            for pkt in pkt_seq:
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/protocol.py", line 275, in read_pkt_seq
            pkt = self.read_pkt_line()
                  ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/dulwich/protocol.py", line 223, in read_pkt_line
            pkt_contents = read(size - 4)
                           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 879, in read
            data = self._raw_read(amt)
                   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 813, in _raw_read
            with self._error_catcher():
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/contextlib.py", line 155, in __exit__
            self.gen.throw(typ, value, traceback)
          File "/usr/lib/python3.11/site-packages/urllib3/response.py", line 727, in _error_catcher
            raise ProtocolError(f"Connection broken: {e!r}", e) from e
        urllib3.exceptions.ProtocolError: ('Connection broken: IncompleteRead(7577 bytes read)', IncompleteRead(7577 bytes read))
```
We would expect this to result in GitProtocolError.

issue.title: Pulls on shallow clones raising KeyError
issue.body:
```
from dulwich.porcelain import pull
repo = clone('<git-url>', 'out', depth=1)

... commit changes to your repo
pull(repo, force=True)

```

As reported here but for pushes:
https://github.com/dulwich/dulwich/pull/757

Pulls on shallow clones are failing on `get_parents` from a commit id is raising `KeyError` from here: https://github.com/dulwich/dulwich/blob/master/dulwich/repo.py#L309


(related to this: https://github.com/dulwich/dulwich/issues/705)

comment.body:
Poetry uses dulwich to install python dependencies from a github repo, there they are getting `KeyError` from dulwich when I try to install a repo with `poetry -vvv add "git+https://github.com/alexander-akhmetov/python-telegram.git"`
```
   2  .venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/poetry/vcs/git/backend.py:171 in get_revision
       169│     def get_revision(repo: Repo) -> str:
       170│         with repo:
     → 171│             return repo.head().decode("utf-8")
       172│ 
       173│     @classmethod

   1  .venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dulwich/repo.py:636 in head
        634│     def head(self) -> bytes:
        635│         """Return the SHA1 pointed at by HEAD."""
     →  636│         return self.refs[b"HEAD"]
        637│ 
        638│     def _get_object(self, sha, cls):

  KeyError

  b'HEAD'

  at .venv/lib/python3.10/site-packages/dulwich/refs.py:325 in __getitem__
       321│         This method follows all symbolic references.
       322│         """
       323│         _, sha = self.follow(name)
       324│         if sha is None:
    →  325│             raise KeyError(name)
       326│         return sha
       327│ 
       328│     def set_if_equals(
       329│         self,
```
Related to their issue https://github.com/python-poetry/poetry/issues/6873

My poetry version is `1.6.1`. I wonder if this is a issue with dulwich.

issue.title: Incorrect Links in Documentation Overview Section
issue.body:
On the Dulwich documentation website (https://www.dulwich.io/docs/), within the "Overview" section, there is a problem with two hyperlinks that are currently leading users to the incorrect locations:
- AUTHORS
- CONTRIBUTING

I am interested in contributing to this issue by rectifying these hyperlinks.

commits.message:
config: handle malformed git submodules (#1224)

A git submodule needs two items in its config: url to clone from, path
to clone to. If either is missing, core git simply ignores this
submodule entry. Dulwich should do the same.
